title: Question 183

children: A 42-year-old woman is evaluated after being transferred from an acute care hospital to a skilled nursing facility. She is bedbound with a spinal cord injury.

On physical examination, vital signs are normal. Three 1- to 2-cm, nonblanching, erythematous, shallow ulcers with no purulence or necrosis are noted over the sacrum and bilateral ischial tuberosities.
Hydrocolloid dressings are applied, and frequent repositioning is instituted.
Which of the following is the most appropriate additional treatment?
Patients at risk for or diagnosed with pressure injuries should be repositioned a minimum of every 2 hours to reduce pressure on jeopardized tissue.

Foam mattresses or foam overlays have been shown to reduce the incidence of pressure injury postoperatively, which is the basis for recommending foam mattresses or overlays for medical inpatients and others at risk.
The most appropriate treatment for this patient's pressure injuries is pressure redistribution and use of a foam mattress or foam mattress overlay (

). Limited evidence suggests that patients at risk for or diagnosed with pressure injuries should be repositioned a minimum of every 2 hours to reduce pressure on jeopardized tissue. It is important to avoid generating shear forces or friction during this procedure. The other element in pressure redistribution is the use of a pressure-reducing support surface. Many different categories of support surfaces are available, and within each category, there are a variety of different products. Head-to-head comparisons of support surfaces are generally lacking, and available evidence is weak. However, high-quality foam mattresses or foam overlays have been shown to reduce the incidence of pressure injury postoperatively. This is the basis for recommending foam mattresses or overlays for medical inpatients and others at risk. Foam mattresses and overlays have the advantages of availability and relatively low cost.
There are no studies to suggest that hyperbaric oxygen therapy (

) is beneficial for pressure injury. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy has been used in the treatment of other types of wounds, and although some short-term benefits can be seen with certain wounds, evidence of long-term benefits is lacking.

Failure of healing may be the primary manifestation of infection in some patients. Fever and leukocytosis are typically absent. This patient does have some nonblanching erythema around the ulcers, but this alone does not indicate infection or need for antibiotics. Empiric treatment with imipenem and vancomycin would be indicted in patients with severe cellulitis and deep soft tissue infection or with sepsis.
No evidence exists to support the use of zinc or vitamin C (
) in treating pressure injuries. Low- to moderate-strength evidence for use of protein-containing nutritional supplements has been demonstrated.

references: Munoz N, Posthauer ME, Cereda E, et al. The role of nutrition for pressure injury prevention and healing: the 2019 international clinical practice guideline recommendations. Adv Skin Wound Care. 2020;33:123-136.
